unnormalised: So, someone asked me about health identifiers. It's actually something my family went through a few years ago. My mother, Asha Devi, had a medical emergency, and navigating the insurance paperwork was a nightmare. We had her health insurance policy number which was a string of seemingly random characters like "HD1234567890", her Aadhaar no. which is "XXXX-YYYY-ZZZZ", and then the hospital wanted her Unique Health Identification (UHID) number, which, if I remember correctly, started with "MH" followed by a long series of digits. It felt like we were drowning in numbers!
normalised: So, someone asked me about health identifiers. It is actually something my family went through a few years ago. My mother, Asha Devi, had a medical emergency, and navigating the insurance paperwork was a nightmare. We had her health insurance policy number which was a string of seemingly random characters like H-D one two three four five six seven eight nine zero, her Aadhaar number which is X-X-X-X dash Y-Y-Y-Y dash Z-Z-Z-Z, and then the hospital wanted her Unique Health Identification (U-H-I-D) number, which, if I remember correctly, started with M-H followed by a long series of digits. It felt like we were drowning in numbers!

unnormalised: The hospital registration desk kept asking for different IDs, and each seemed to be for a different purpose. We had her old insurance card with an expiry date of 07/2023, but they needed the updated policy details which, of course, I hadn't carried with me. They even asked if she had a CGHS card since she's a retired government teacher, but that had a different registration number altogether – something like "CGHS/DL/12345". Each system felt so disconnected!
normalised: The hospital registration desk kept asking for different I-Ds, and each seemed to be for a different purpose. We had her old insurance card with an expiry date of july two thousand twenty three, but they needed the updated policy details which, of course, I had not carried with me. They even asked if she had a C-G-H-S card since she is a retired government teacher, but that had a different registration number altogether – something like C-G-H-S slash D-L slash one two three four five. Each system felt so disconnected!

unnormalised: I distinctly remember the clerk asking, "Madamji, what is your Central Govt. Health Scheme card no.?" and then proceeding to input it in a system that didn't seem to talk to the health insurance system. It was frustrating because all this was happening while my mother needed immediate medical attention. I mean, couldn't they just use her Aadhaar number "XXXX-YYYY-ZZZZ" and pull up all her relevant healthcare information?
normalised: I distinctly remember the clerk asking, "Madamji, what is your Central Government Health Scheme card number?" and then proceeding to input it in a system that did not seem to talk to the health insurance system. It was frustrating because all this was happening while my mother needed immediate medical attention. I mean, could not they just use her Aadhaar number X-X-X-X dash Y-Y-Y-Y dash Z-Z-Z-Z and pull up all her relevant healthcare information?

unnormalised: I later learned that there are initiatives to create a more unified health ID system in India, something like the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (ABHA) ID. I haven't looked into it deeply, but the idea is to link all your health records to a single ID. Hopefully, it'll make things easier for families in similar situations, so no one has to juggle multiple health identifiers like "HD1234567890", "CGHS/DL/12345", and UHIDs all at once during a crisis.
normalised: I later learned that there are initiatives to create a more unified health I-D system in India, something like the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (A-B-H-A) I-D. I have not looked into it deeply, but the idea is to link all your health records to a single I-D. Hopefully, it will make things easier for families in similar situations, so no one has to juggle multiple health identifiers like H-D one two three four five six seven eight nine zero, C-G-H-S slash D-L slash one two three four five, and U-H-I-Ds all at once during a crisis.

unnormalised: Honestly, streamlining these identifiers would make a world of difference, especially for senior citizens like my mother, Asha Devi. We need a system that prioritizes patient care over bureaucratic hurdles. I truly hope the government focuses more on simplifying this process for everyone.
